## Introduction: Developing Websites Locally




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The goal of this unit is to introduce you to text editors and how to develop websites on your own computer. You will also learn about Chrome DevTools, an essential tool used to analyze a web page’s HTML and CSS.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">After this unit, you will be able to:</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Use text editors to develop websites locally</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Use Chrome DevTools to inspect webpages in the browser</li>
</ul>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Learning is social. Whatever you’re working on, be sure to connect with the Codecademy community in the <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://discuss.codecademy.com/">forums</a>. Remember to check in with the community regularly, including for things like asking for code reviews on your project work and providing code reviews to others in the <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://discuss.codecademy.com/c/project/1833">projects category</a>, which can help to reinforce what you’ve learned.</p>
</div>




## Getting Started with Visual Studio Code




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In this article, we will go over the steps necessary to download a popular text editor called Visual Studio Code, also referred to as “VS Code.” By the end of this article, you will be all set up to start interacting with code using VS Code! </p>
<h2 id="heading-i-introduction" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">I. Introduction</h2>
<h3 id="heading-what-are-text-editors" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">What are ‘text editors’?</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Text editors, also called code editors, are applications used by developers to write code. They can highlight and format your code so that it’s easier to read and understand. If you’ve used Codecademy, you’re already familiar with a text editor. It’s the area you write your code in. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Using a text editor is part of creating your “development environment,” the set of tools that you use for working on coding projects. It will allow you to take what you’ve learned on Codecademy and put it into practice as you work on projects on your computer. Not only will this introduce you to tools that are commonly used by professional developers but it also means that you’ve grown as a developer and are ready to start working on your own—great work!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Specific to writing code, text editors provide a number of advantages:</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Language-specific syntax highlighting</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Automatic code indentation</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Color schemes to suit your preferences and make code easier to read</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Plug-ins, or add-on programs, to catch errors in code</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">A tree view, or visual representation, of a project’s folders and files, so you can conveniently navigate your project</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Key shortcuts, or combinations, for faster development</li>
</ul>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You may also have read or heard about IDEs, or “integrated development environments.” An IDE allows you to not only edit, but also compile, and debug your code through one application or interface. While the text editor we recommend isn’t considered an IDE, it has many IDE-like features that make life as a developer easier without needing a lot of resources that an IDE usually requires. The best of both worlds!</p>
<h3 id="heading-choosing-a-text-editor" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Choosing a Text Editor</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">There are a number of text editors to choose from. For example, Visual Studio Code is one of the most popular text editors used by developers. (That’s Visual Studio Code and not Visual Studio, which is slightly different. We want the former, the one with ‘Code’ in the name.) Other popular text editors you may have heard of are Atom and Sublime Text. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Any of these text editors mentioned are great for development but to make things easier, we suggest you start off with Visual Studio Code. Some of the benefits of this editor are:</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Free to use</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Open-source, (meaning a program’s code can be viewed, modified, and shared)</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">IDE-like features</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Supported by a large community of users and Microsoft</li>
</ul>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When you are further along in your coding career, you can try other code editors to see what features work best with your personal development workflow. </p>
<h2 id="heading-ii-installing-visual-studio-code" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">II. Installing Visual Studio Code</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">So, we’ve chosen our text editor, now we just need to install it on our computer! </p>
<h3 id="heading-video-instructions" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Video Instructions</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">For visual learners, this video details how to download and install Visual Studio Code. Written instructions are below.  </p>
<div class="videoWrapper__3R1U9Yh5QHTJ4KWKzUNHPH iframe__rk2yNYIwJeUOj5J8cQJ9-"><div class="iframe__25_Eo0IL9_7ud9AX98_92S" style="width: 640px; height: 360px;"><div style="width: 100%; height: 100%;"><iframe frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" title="Intro to Visual Studio Code" width="100%" height="100%" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Do0tl_u0WZk?autoplay=0&amp;mute=0&amp;controls=1&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.codecademy.com&amp;playsinline=1&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;widgetid=1" id="widget2" data-gtm-yt-inspected-76="true"></iframe></div></div></div>

<h3 id="heading-installation-steps" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Installation Steps</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The installation process for computers running macOS, Windows, and Linux, (specifically Ubuntu and Debian), will be very similar. Also, using Visual Studio Code across all of them will be the same. </p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Visit the <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/">Visual Studio Code website</a> to download the latest version of Visual Studio Code. </p>
<img src="https://content.codecademy.com/articles/visual-studio-code/vsc-screenshot.png" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp">
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You should see your computer’s operating system displayed, but if it’s not correct, click on the down arrow  and find the option that matches your operating system from the drop-down menu, and click on the down arrow icon under “Stable.”</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Windows users:</strong> This will download the latest version of Visual Studio Code as an .exe file.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Mac users:</strong> This will download the latest version of Visual Studio Code for Mac as a .zip file.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Linux users:</strong> .deb and .rpm are different file types for storing data. We suggest you download the .deb file so auto-updates work as the Visual Studio Code documentation suggests.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Once the Visual Studio Code file is finished downloading, we need to install it. Find the Visual Studio Code file in your file manager, the program that lets you see the files and folders on your computer. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Windows users:</strong> Open the .exe file by clicking on it and on run the installer. Keep clicking ‘Next’ and then finally ‘Finish.’</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Mac users:</strong> The downloaded .zip file should be in your ‘Downloads’ folder. Open the file. If you see this message  choose “Open.”</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Linux users:</strong> The downloaded file should be in your ‘Downloads’ folder. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Find it in your file manager, double click and choose ‘Install’ in the GUI software center, or run the following commands, one at a time, in the terminal:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">sudo dpkg -i downloaded_filename.deb</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">sudo apt-get install -f</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre></li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Make sure you have your Visual Studio Code application saved in a place you know you will easily be able to find it.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Windows users:</strong> It will automatically be placed in your Start menu.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Mac users:</strong> Click and drag the Visual Studio Code icon from the Downloads folder to the Applications folder.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Linux users:</strong> It should appear in your taskbar of programs.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">That’s it, you’ve successfully installed your text editor and are ready to start coding! </p>
</div>




## Building Projects with VS Code




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><h2 id="heading-practice-using-visual-studio-code-to-start-an-off-platform-project" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Practice using Visual Studio Code to start an off-platform project</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As you move through various lessons and paths here on Codecademy, you may find yourself needing to create a project on your own computer and not on the Codecademy learning environment. This can be tricky, but it’s an exciting step that signals that you are ready to work independently.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">To do this, we’ll need to use a <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/general/code-editor">code editor</a>, we recommend <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/">Visual Studio Code</a> (or “VS Code”).</p>
<h3 id="heading-what-are-development-folders" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">What are development folders?</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Before using your text editor, it’s important to establish an organized <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/general/file-paths">file system</a>. As the number and size of your projects grow, it becomes increasingly important to know where to save new projects and find old projects.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Most developers store their projects in an easy-to-find directory, (what you might be used to calling a “folder”). Here at Codecademy, we recommend naming this folder as <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code>. It will store all of your coding projects. Whenever you create a new project, no matter how small, you should always make a new folder inside your <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code> directory. You will find that single-file projects can quickly turn into larger, multi-folder projects.</p>
<h3 id="heading-lets-make-a-project" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Let’s make a project</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Below are the steps you need to follow to create a new folder for all of your programming projects. You will also learn how to load a new project folder into VS Code and make your very first “hello world” HTML project.</p>
<div class="videoWrapper__3R1U9Yh5QHTJ4KWKzUNHPH iframe__rk2yNYIwJeUOj5J8cQJ9-"><div class="iframe__25_Eo0IL9_7ud9AX98_92S" style="width: 640px; height: 360px;"><div style="width: 100%; height: 100%;"><iframe frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" title="How to create a website" width="100%" height="100%" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/47GaFnnex5w?autoplay=0&amp;mute=0&amp;controls=1&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.codecademy.com&amp;playsinline=1&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;widgetid=1" id="widget2" data-gtm-yt-inspected-76="true"></iframe></div></div></div>

<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">We’d recommend that you watch the above video and then follow the written steps below.</p>
<h5 id="heading-1-make-a-development-folder">1. Make a development folder</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Navigate to a folder using your file manager or the terminal. Make sure it is a folder you visit regularly and will remember. Create a new folder called <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code>.</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><strong>macOS users:</strong> This may be your user account or <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Home</code> folder.</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><strong>Windows users:</strong> You may want to save this on your <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">C:</code> drive.</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><strong>Linux users:</strong> You may want to save this in your user folder inside of the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">home</code> folder.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Inside the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code> directory, create a new folder called <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">HelloWorld</code>. Everything you add to this folder will be part of your <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">HelloWorld</code> project.</p>
<h5 id="heading-2-open-vs-code">2. Open VS Code</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">For this step, VS Code will need to be <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/download">downloaded</a>. Then, it can either be launched with the desktop icon or by opening a <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/general/terminal">terminal</a> and doing the following:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Change into the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code> directory with the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">cd</code> command:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="shell" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">cd projects</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Open VS Code from the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">projects</code> directory with the following command:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="shell" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">code .</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
</li>
</ol>
<blockquote class="blockquote__Bo1k0tPllp684-m2XzKRP">
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Note:</strong> Depending on the operating system, there may be some extra steps needed to <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/command-line#_launching-from-command-line">launch VS Code from the terminal</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<h5 id="heading-3-open-your-development-folder">3. Open your development folder</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Click on the “Explorer” icon on the left-hand menu and click on the “Open Folder” button and choose your development folder. This will launch your file manager.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Navigate to the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">HelloWorld/</code> folder and select Open. The folder will open in VS Code’s side pane. At this point, there should not be any contents in the folder. We’ll add a file in the next step.</p>
<h5 id="heading-4-add-a-file">4. Add a file</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Before you learn how to add files to a project folder, it is important to understand the purpose of <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/general/file-formats">file formats</a>. File formats include the file <em>extension</em>, or the suffix of a filename (the last 3 - 4 characters in a filename, preceded by a period <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.</code>), and describe the type of content the file contains. For example, the HTML file extension is <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.html</code>, and it tells the browser (and other applications) to interpret the contents of the file as an HTML document. Once VS Code loads a project folder, you can add files. The steps below describe how to add files. Don’t worry about doing this on your own computer. We’ll get to that next.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In VS Code’s “Explorer” pane, click on your development folder’s name. You’ll see four icons appear to the right of the folder name. Click the “New File” icon. Type the new file’s name with its appropriate file extension ( e.g., <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.html</code>, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.css</code>, and <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.csv</code>). It is critical that you include the correct <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/general/file-paths">file path</a>, so programs like linters know how to interpret its contents. Press <kbd>Enter</kbd> when done.</p>
<h5 id="heading-5-begin-coding">5. Begin coding</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Copy and paste the following boilerplate HTML code:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-html" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;html&gt;</span><span class="mtk1"> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;head&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;title&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Hello World</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/title&gt;</span><span class="mtk1"> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/head&gt;</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;body&gt;</span><span class="mtk1"> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;h1&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Hello World</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/h1&gt;</span><span class="mtk1"> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/body&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/html&gt;</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">To decrease the chances of losing unsaved work, save your file often with the Auto Save feature and track changes with a version control system, like <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/resources/docs/git">Git</a>, if you know how to use one. (To turn Auto Save on, click on “File”, then “Auto Save”. When it’s on, you’ll see a checkmark next to “Auto Save”.)</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>File Formats and Syntax Highlighting</strong></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Syntax is the set of rules that tell us how to create correctly written code. VS Code and other text editors are able to interpret file formats and provide language-specific syntax highlighting. Syntax highlighting is a tool for making code easier to read. Take a look at your index.html file. The text and tags are different colors. This is how VS Code highlights .html syntax. With each new language you learn, VS Code will highlight text in a way that makes your code easy to read. This may be different than other text editors and also different than the way your code is highlighted on Codecademy.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><strong>Optional: Change the color scheme</strong></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Although VS Code comes with default syntax highlighting, you may want to change the colors used. Good color themes will make reading all those lines of code easy on your eyes. (Try out low contrast, dark themes like “Solarized Dark” or “Dracula Dark.”) </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">To do this, select Color Theme from the Welcome page when you first open VS Code, or click on Code in the menu bar at the top of your desktop window, then click on Preferences, followed by Color Theme. You can also search for color themes to install using the Extensions menu. </p>
<h5 id="heading-6-view-your-html-file-in-the-browser">6. View your HTML file in the browser</h5>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">At this point, your file is ready to be viewed in a web browser. The following steps should be taken outside of VS Code:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Navigate to the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">index.html</code> file in your Hello World folder through your file manager or terminal.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Double-click or open <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">index.html</code>. The page should open in your default web browser. Take a second to marvel at your handiwork — you made your first project with VS Code.</p>
<h2 id="heading-wrapping-up" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Wrapping up</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Congratulations, you’ve successfully used your VS Code text editor to create a website — all on your own computer! As you work more with VS Code, you’ll get a better sense of how to personalize it to fit your needs. Don’t be afraid to experiment and try out different things!</p>
<h3 id="heading-go-further-with-vs-codes-features" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Go further with VS Code’s features</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">If you already feel comfortable with the previous steps, explore the following features to further customize your development environment. You don’t need to use these suggestions to complete the projects on Codecademy but they can help make you more efficient when writing code. They are part of are what makes VS Code such a useful editor!</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/debugging"><strong>Debugging code in the editor:</strong></a> That’s right, you can run and test code from the editor! </p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/versioncontrol"><strong>Version control:</strong></a> You don’t need to switch to the terminal on your computer to track changes with Git.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/integrated-terminal"><strong>Integrated terminal:</strong></a> You can run command line commands from your editor with VS Code.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>




## Create Your First Local HTML/CSS Project




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Requirements:</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Text editor (we recommend VS Code)</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">An Internet browser</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="heading-introduction" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Introduction</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In this article, we’ll cover how to take the CSS skills you’ve learned on Codecademy and use them to create a basic web page built entirely from the tools you have on your computer. Before you proceed, you should already be familiar with the basics of text editors, local files, and directories, all of which are covered <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/articles/visual-studio-code">elsewhere</a> on Codecademy.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">We recommend that you watch this explainer video and then follow the instructions below.</p>
<div class="videoWrapper__3R1U9Yh5QHTJ4KWKzUNHPH iframe__rk2yNYIwJeUOj5J8cQJ9-"><div class="iframe__25_Eo0IL9_7ud9AX98_92S" style="width: 640px; height: 360px;"><div style="width: 100%; height: 100%;"><iframe frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" title="Create your first HTML/CSS project" width="100%" height="100%" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wzWmZYi4qMg?autoplay=0&amp;mute=0&amp;controls=1&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.codecademy.com&amp;playsinline=1&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;widgetid=1" id="widget2" data-gtm-yt-inspected-76="true"></iframe></div></div></div>

<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">If you’d like some optional extra guidance on real-world CSS, watch the <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://youtu.be/EGMSlY2v5xk">second part</a> of the video.</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-1-create-a-folder-structure-for-your-web-page" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 1: Create a Folder Structure For Your Web Page</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s create a  folder structure to support your web page. A well-designed folder structure will help you quickly navigate to the HTML or CSS files that contain your code. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">First, open Finder (in Mac) or Explorer (in Windows). Next, create a folder (also known as a directory) called <strong>DevProject</strong>. This folder will contain all of the files for your HTML and CSS project.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Open the <strong>DevProject</strong> folder. Inside, create the following items:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">A new file called <strong>index.html</strong> (use your preferred text editor)</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">A new folder called <strong>resources</strong></li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <strong>index.html</strong> file will contain the HTML code for your web page, while the <strong>resources</strong> folder will contain all of the necessary resources needed by the HTML files (CSS files, images, etc.).</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Next, open the newly created <strong>resources</strong> folder. Inside of this folder, create the following:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">An additional folder named <strong>css</strong> </li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <strong>css</strong> folder will contain the CSS files needed to style your web page.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Finally, open the <strong>css</strong> folder you just created. Inside of this folder, create the following:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">A new file named <strong>index.css</strong> (use your preferred text editor)</li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <strong>index.css</strong> file will contain all of the CSS styling rules that will be applied to your web page.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">This overall folder structure will help support your workflow as you add files or resources. At a high-level, here’s what it should look like:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/filesystem-start.svg" alt="filesystem" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<h4 id="heading-step-2-add-content-to-your-web-page" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 2: Add Content To Your Web Page</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Great! With your folder structure, HTML, and CSS files all in the right place, we can add content to the web page.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">First, open the <strong>index.html</strong> file in your preferred text editor. Next, add the required boilerplate HTML code:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-html" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk16">&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;html&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;head&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;title&gt;&lt;/title&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/head&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;body&gt;</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/body&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/html&gt;</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">After you add the boilerplate HTML code, feel free to also add the following items:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Your own title between the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">&lt;title&gt;</code> tags</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Your own content within the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">&lt;body&gt;</code> tags. If you need some quick, pre-written content, feel free to use the following and modify as you wish:</li>
</ol>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-html" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;h1&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">FirstName LastName</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/h1&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;p&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">I'm learning to code on Codecademy! My goals inclu</span><span class="mtk1">de:</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/p&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;ul&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;li&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Learn to code</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/li&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;li&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Start a&nbsp;company</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/li&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;li&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Help the world</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/li&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/ul&gt;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;p&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">This is one of my favorite websites: </span><span class="mtk4">&lt;a</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk7">href</span><span class="mtk1">=</span><span class="mtk8">"https://www.google.com/"</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk7">target</span><span class="mtk1">=</span><span class="mtk8">"_blank"</span><span class="mtk4">&gt;</span><span class="mtk1">Google</span><span class="mtk4">&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Finally, open the <strong>index.css</strong> file in your preferred text editor. Add the following pre-written CSS rules to the file (feel free to modify as you wish):</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-css" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk4">*</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk1">{</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk10">font-family</span><span class="mtk1">:</span><span class="mtk9"> Helvetica</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk9"> Arial</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk5">sans-serif</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">h1</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk1">{</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk10">color</span><span class="mtk1">:</span><span class="mtk9"> SeaGreen</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">p</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk9"> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">li</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk1">{</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk10">font-size</span><span class="mtk1">:</span><span class="mtk9"> 18px</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk4">a</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk1">{</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk10">text-decoration</span><span class="mtk1">:</span><span class="mtk9"> </span><span class="mtk12">none</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Be sure to save your changes for both files!</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-3-link-your-html-file-and-css-file" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 3: Link Your HTML File and CSS File</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As it turns out, the HTML content you added will not be styled by the CSS rules unless <strong>index.html</strong> and <strong>index.css</strong> are linked together. In the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">&lt;head&gt;</code> section, link the stylesheet to the HTML file.</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-html" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk4">&lt;link</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk7">href</span><span class="mtk1">=</span><span class="mtk8">"./resources/css/index.css"</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk7">type</span><span class="mtk1">=</span><span class="mtk8">"text/css"</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk7">rel</span><span class="mtk1">=</span><span class="mtk8">"stylesheet"</span><span class="mtk4">&gt;</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You might be wondering why the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">href</code> attribute is set to <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">./resources/css/index.css</code>. This is because you must specify exactly where the <strong>index.css</strong> file lives within your folder(s) <em>relative</em> to where <strong>index.html</strong> lives (otherwise, the two files won’t link). </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">If you have trouble linking your HTML and CSS, head to the <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://discuss.codecademy.com/t/how-do-i-link-my-html-and-css/423288">Codecademy community forums</a> for help.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Again, make sure to save your changes!</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-4-view-your-project" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 4: View Your Project</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Great work - let’s take a look at your web page in the browser. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Open your preferred web browser. In the menu bar, click on “File” and then click on “Open File…” (or equivalent). Navigate to your <strong>index.html</strong> file and then click “Open” (or equivalent). The browser should load your web page. What do you see?</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">At this point, feel free to make changes to your HTML or CSS code. Keep in mind that in order to view any <em>new</em> changes you make, you’ll have to refresh your browser.</p>
<h4 id="heading-review" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Review</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Congrats! In this short time, you learned how to take what you’ve been learning on Codecademy and apply it using the tools you have available on your own personal computer. You successfully learned how to:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Create a folder structure to support both your workflow and your web page</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Add HTML content and CSS styling to respective files</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Link the HTML and CSS files together</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">View your web page in a browser (and refresh the browser to view new changes)</li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In general, the four points above are a strong starting point for your own developer workflow. As you learn more, you may modify the workflow to fit your specific needs. At this point, feel free to modify the content of the web page or create an entirely new project. Happy coding! </p>
</div>




## Intro to Chrome Devtools




<iframe frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" title="Chrome DevTools" width="100%" height="100%" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VuQ4pF_hfag?autoplay=0&amp;mute=0&amp;controls=1&amp;origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.codecademy.com&amp;playsinline=1&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;widgetid=1" id="widget2" data-gtm-yt-inspected-76="true"></iframe>




## CSS Visual Rules in Chrome Inspector




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><h2 id="heading-using-chrome-devtools-for-css-visual-rules" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Using Chrome DevTools for CSS Visual Rules</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Requirements:</p>
<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">An Internet browser</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="heading-introduction" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Introduction</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Browser developer tools allow web developers to quickly collect important information on most websites. These tools are available within most major web browsers, like Chrome, Safari, and Firefox, to name a few. Because Google Chrome is the preferred browser for many professional developers, we’ll learn how to use the browser developer tools within Google Chrome, known as Chrome DevTools. </p>
<h4 id="heading-step-1-accessing-devtools" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 1: Accessing DevTools</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The quickest way of accessing DevTools in Chrome is to navigate to any website (like this one) and <em>right click</em> (press <kbd>control</kbd> and click for a single button mouse) anywhere on the page. Upon doing so, a menu will appear directly beside the area you clicked on. In the menu, select “Inspect.” This will automatically launch DevTools within your browser. DevTools will appear as a window on either the bottom or right-hand side of your screen. It should look something like this: </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/devtools.png" alt="devtools" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You should see the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Elements</code>, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Console</code>, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Sources</code>, and <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Network</code> tabs, among many others. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">This rest of this article will focus exclusively on the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Elements</code> tab.</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-2-using-devtools-to-view-css-styles" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 2: Using DevTools to View CSS Styles</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">DevTools can provide you with a lot of information about a website, but it’s particularly exceptional at examining a page’s HTML elements, along with the CSS styles for those respective elements. Let’s try it out!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">1. Open an incognito Chrome browser (in the browser’s menu, click on “File” then “New Incognito Window”). This will allow you to read this article while completing the following steps.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">2. Navigate to <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://codecademy.com/">Codecademy’s homepage</a> (make sure you are logged out).  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">3. Right click (or <kbd>control</kbd> and click simultaneously) on any text on the page. (This article uses screenshots from a previous version of the Codecademy home page. Your home page may look different from the one shown in the screenshots.)</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">4. Select “Inspect” in the menu that appears.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">5. DevTools should appear at the bottom of your page (it’s normal if its appears in another location, as its location can be changed).  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">6. Click on the “Elements” tab of DevTools (if you’re not already on it).  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/click-on-elements-tab.jpg" alt="elementstab" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">7. In the left pane, notice the interactive DOM (HTML elements) that contains the current content of the web page.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">8. Mouse over the HTML code — as you mouse over, notice that DevTools will highlight the corresponding HTML element on the web page.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">9. Note that you can expand closed elements by clicking the arrow directly to the left of them.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/expand-element.jpg" alt="expandelement" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">10. Alternatively, click the “Select element” icon (shown in the image below) in the top-left corner of the console and then click on an element within the web page — this is a much quicker way of accessing a specific element on the web page that you want to inspect.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/select-element.jpg" alt="selectelement" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">11. On the right hand side of DevTools, click on the tab named <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> (if you’re not already on it) — this tab displays <em>all</em> of the CSS styles associated with the element highlighted in the left side of DevTools.  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">12. Scroll down in the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> tab, notice that some CSS styles are crossed out with a horizontal black line.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/unused-styles.jpg" alt="unused" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">13. Remember, the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> tab shows <em>all</em> styles applied to that element (rules can often be overwritten by more specific rules, which causes the horizontal black line through some CSS rules, denoting that that rule is not being used).  </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">14. To instead view <em>only</em> the styles applied to that specific element, click on the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Computed</code> tab directly next to the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> tab in the right pane. In this pane, you will see only the styles that are being applied to that element, also known as the <em>computed styles</em>. (If the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Computed</code> tab is not appearing for you, your browser may be sized too small. Expand the width of the browser until it appears.)</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/computed-tab.jpg" alt="computed" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<h4 id="heading-step-3-modifying-css-styles-with-devtools" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 3: Modifying CSS Styles with DevTools</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">DevTools is also useful for modifying <em>existing</em> CSS rules and previewing those changes directly on the page you’re viewing. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">To try it out, click again on the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> tab in the right pane of DevTools (feel free to use the Codecademy website again). Scroll down to a CSS rule (one that is <em>not</em> crossed out with a black line), click on the value of any applied CSS rule, change the value, and press <kbd>enter</kbd> on your keyboard. You should see the change automatically update on the page. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/edit-a-style.jpg" alt="editStyles" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">There are a few things to keep in mind when using DevTools to modify a web page:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">1. When you modify or change a CSS rule, you may be affecting more than one element.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">2. DevTools provides easy-to-use tools when you modify certain CSS rules. (For example, when modifying color values, DevTools will provide you with a color picker to help you select a color.)</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">3. DevTools is only a <em>sandbox</em> tool, meaning that any changes you make to the web page will <em>not be saved</em>, so make sure to write down any changes you’d like to make when using DevTools for your own web page!</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-4-add-css-styles-with-devtools" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 4: Add CSS Styles with DevTools</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In addition to modifying existing CSS rules, you can add <em>new</em> CSS rules as well. Let’s continue using DevTools on the Codecademy homepage.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">1. Locate some text on the home page (i.e. find a heading, paragraph, link, etc.).</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">2. Right click on the text and click “Inspect” in the menu that appears. DevTools will highlight the corresponding HTML element in its left pane.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">3. Take a look at the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Styles</code> tab and click on the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">+</code> icon in the top-right corner of the right pane — notice that this creates a new, empty CSS rule for that element.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">4. Within the element’s selector, click and add a new CSS declaration. The following is an example (feel free to add your own declaration):</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-css" class="gamut-1oq8wcb-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk4">background-color</span><span class="mtk9">: </span><span class="mtk4">red</span><span class="mtk9">;</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You should see the background color of the text you selected change to red. You can also continue to add your own CSS styling as you wish.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the future, try this technique on your own website(s) as you build them from the ground up. Building with DevTools can result in a more efficient workflow, as it can help you avoid repeatedly saving and viewing changes manually.</p>
<h4 id="heading-step-5-modify-html-with-devtools" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Step 5: Modify HTML with DevTools</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">DevTools also lets you directly <em>modify</em> the HTML content of a web page. Let’s try this out one more time on the Codecademy homepage.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">1. Again, right click on a piece of text on the homepage and click “Inspect” in the menu that appears.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">2. DevTools will automatically highlight the HTML code in the left pane associated with the content that you inspected on the web page.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">3. In DevTools, double click on the text between the opening and closing tags of the text you right-clicked on.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">4. Change the heading to say something else, like your name, or “Codecademy”, and press <kbd>enter</kbd>.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://content.codecademy.com/courses/freelance-1/unit-2/edit-an-element.jpg" alt="editElement" class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">At this point, you should see the text change!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You can also add HTML of your own as well. Let’s add an <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">&lt;h2&gt;</code> element directly below the element you just modified.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">1. Right click on the element you just modified, a menu should appear. Click on “Edit as HTML.” (You can also delete elements using this menu.)</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">2. A large text field should appear. Directly edit the HTML by adding an <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">&lt;h2&gt;</code> element below with the text of your choice. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">3. To complete/view your changes, click on any other element in the left window pane or press <kbd>command</kbd> and <kbd>enter</kbd> at the same time (on a Mac keyboard).</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">What happens to the web page? Remember, these are sandboxed changes, so your changes will <em>not</em> be saved, nor permanently affect the website you are applying changes to.</p>
<h4 id="heading-review" class="h4__1cJx3E4QhkKjfWj3jLsTFU">Review</h4>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The Chrome web browser provides you with robust web developer tools known as DevTools. With DevTools, you can view a web page’s existing DOM elements and associated styles, as well as modify and preview changes you make to the web page, resulting in an efficient workflow. If you’re interested in learning more about DevTools, visit the official documentation at <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.chrome.com/devtools">https://developer.chrome.com/devtools</a>.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Happy coding!</p>
</div>
